videos.title: Sort Colors - Dutch National Flag - Leetcode 75
Sort 0s 1s and 2s | Dutch National Flag Algorithm

patternTriggers: Use Three Pointers (Dutch National Flag) when you need to partition an array into three sections based on values, especially for sorting with limited distinct values.

approaches.name: Counting Sort
approaches.intuition: Count occurrences of each color (0, 1, 2) and then overwrite the array with the correct counts.
approaches.approach: Make two passes: first to count, second to write back the values in sorted order.

approaches.name: Dutch National Flag (Optimal)
approaches.intuition: Use three pointers to partition the array in one pass. Keep all 0s on the left, all 2s on the right, and 1s will naturally be in the middle.
approaches.approach: Maintain three pointers: low (for 0s), mid (current element), and high (for 2s). Process elements and swap them to their correct positions.

commonMistakes: Incrementing mid pointer after swapping with high (should check swapped element first)
Using wrong loop condition (should be mid <= high, not mid < high)
Not understanding why mid doesn't increment when swapping with high
Trying to sort in descending order by mistake
hints: Think about partitioning the array into three sections
All 0s should be on the left, all 2s on the right, 1s in the middle
When you swap with the high pointer, you need to examine the swapped element
The mid pointer scans through unprocessed elements
This algorithm is also known as the Dutch National Flag algorithm
followUp: Can you extend this to sort an array with k distinct values?
What if the values are not 0, 1, 2 but three arbitrary distinct values?
How would you sort in descending order?
